Inscription
on verso in graphite: [Neapol. 17. fur Fresko [or Fresken] uber Versch... . (ir...) V.. .. (illegible)]
markings: Watermark: eagle in a circle with crown (61 x 39 mm); chain lines 30 and 35 mm apart
medium: Pen and brown ink, brush and brown wash, on laid paper
provenance: [Herbert Feist, New York, until 1973; sold, June 13, as Roman, 17th century, for $325, to Moir]; Alfred Moir, Santa Barbara (1973- d. 2010; bequeathed to MIA)
text: Raffaello Vanni executed this brisk pen study in preparation for a large wall fresco he painted in the oratory of the Santissima Trinità and church of the Contrada of Valdimontone, in Siena. It depicts the Battle of Vouillé of 507, when King Clovis of France defeated Alaric II, King of the Visigoths of Toulouse. The legendary ancient story would have resonated in the 17th century as an image of Catholic triumph over nonbelievers. The scholars Marco Ciampolini and Alfred Moir identified the related fresco in Siena.
title: Study of a Battle, preparatory sketch for the fresco 'Clovis Defeats Alaric II'
